MAYORAL ELECTION.

Bowen Town Council, 11/4/39. The Editor, "Bowen Independent," Bowen.

Yours faithfully. E. W. RUSSELL, Mayor.

Dear Sir. —I n your issue of the 5th April appears a letter over the signa ture of Dr. Delamothe, one of the Mayoral candidates, regarding the lay-

ing of pipes under bitumen roadways and stating that already one road pro-, pared for bitumen spraying had been dug np for the purpose of repairing a leak in a water pipe. Investigation of this statement shows the necessity for any person, before criticising the ac tions of a Council, to inquire in th« proper quarter as to what Is actually being done. In this particular instance what happened was that a quantify of clayey soil, considered to be unsuit able for good road formation had been deposited in the road In one spot, and the foreman upon inspection had or dered it to he dug out and the proper gravel put in its place. Therefore the question of a leaky water pipe does not come into the argument. Regarding the dilliculty experienced by every Local Authority in connec tion with water mains and the modern types of roadways many cities through out the world are now adopting the expensive method of laying water mains tinder the footpath on each side of the road, but such a method is ob viously far beyond the llnancial re sources of most towns in Australia, lot alone Bowen. Herbert Street between Dalrymple and Williams Street is, however, served this way, so Bowen is not quite out of the picture. As far as the bitumen pavements now being laid down are concerned, the present Council was fully aware of the cost of digging np the road to at tend to leaky wains, not to mention the damage to‘the roads, so it. was arrang ed that till water mains should be laid to one side of these pavements, and not a new bitumen road will cover a water main. The position of house »cr vice pipes unfortunately could not lie overcome and they, must go under the bitumen, but plumbers, when carrying out repairs to these pipes must make good all damage to the roads and the cost to the Council is nil. If anyone can invent an economical method of conveying water from one side of tlie road to the other to serve householders wlihout going under the road, he will confer a blessing on all witter authorities. Dr Delamothe says something about a “time-honoured and hewhlskered idea” for an outgoing Council to save much of its money for a final splurge in the last few weeks of its life. 'This remark cannot play to the present Council, as more than eighty per cent of the loan moneys granted lias been spent, and there are less men employ ed now by the Council titan there were six months ago. .

Bowen Chamber of Commerce.

ANNUAL REPORT FOR THE YEAR ENDED 30TH SEPTEMBER, 1939. TO THE MEMBERS,

R. A. KELSEY. President.

I have pleasure in presenting our annual report in respect of the year ended 30th September. 1939. Since I last so addressed you there has been a grunt, change in world affairs. Germany's continued ruthless aggression has at last resulted in what we all hoped would be avoided—

war. With other British dominions wo are supporting the Mother Country ■and her Ally—France, in this struggle for world freedom. All our re sources in men. ships and produce are being: marshalled for the defence of Australia and assistance to Great Britain. There is so far, 1 am thankful to say, no direct threat of Invasion of Australia, but what the future may hold in store for our country is unpredictable and so our Federal Govern ment. is wisely providing against all possible contingencies by building up a strong army and air force. Whilst we are ail sanguine as to the ultimate result of this struggle we also realise that before the end is reached great sacrifices will have been endured at home and abroad. The position Is faced with a spirit and determination to rid the world of the tyranny of Nazism and to restore to those victims of stark and traitorous aggression in Europe their lost independence. This resolution has a common inspiration throughout the British Empire whose j)eopio will realise the wonderful patience and self control exercis ed by tlio Mother Country in efforts to find peaceful solutions of inter national problems as opposed to brute force. Bike the last this war is none of our seeking but since we are forced to defend ourselves against the-throat of world domination it is unlikely that any pence will be reach ed until that, threat is completely eliminated. It Is good to note that in these efforts we have the moral and, in. many cases, the active support of most nations throughout the world. I feel it is fit as a preamble to our annual report to make the foregoing few observations on conditions so vitally affecting our social, commercial and economic well being, Tlie comprehensive list, of subjects attracting the attention of the Chamber throughout the year is a reflection of the expansion and -prosper ity of our district and is such as to inspire confidence in the future. FARMING. ..Although the rainfall for the year was on the light side, showing a total of only 1942 points for the ten 'months ended October, the man on the- hind enjoyed a fairly prosiierous season. Production was lighter com pared to the previous season, but tills was well offsetted by better market ing, conditions. film following figures of exports were kindly supplied by our-two local organisations. For the nine months ended September the Bowyn Fruit. Export Company exported 813.-171 packages of tomatoes, cucumbers, pineapples, pumpkins, etc., as compared to 239,187 for the corresponding period of last yea) - , while the relative figures for the Committee of Direction were 93,170 packages compared to 120,405 for the preceding period. COAL. For the year ended 30th .Tune 1039, the Bowen Coalfield produced 2171015 tons of coal made up from 158.412 tons from the Bowen State Mine and"sB;oo3 tons from the Bowen Consolidated Colliery, Employment in these two collieries; is provided for upwards of 380 men. The Bowen Coke Works, operated by the Government, treats approximately .50,000 ■ tons of coal annually for a return of around (M l per cent of coke. Prin cipal consumers-are the Mount Isa Company and the State Smulturs v .... salt. - V v Following a .harvest of 9,000 tons for the 1938 season, the Bowen Salt, Company had over 18000 tons of salt in its storage sheds. There is abundance of salt already available for lids season’s harvest but the actual tonnage garnered will depend upon the extent of stora'ge-room available,. This Company has been paying an annual dividend of 7 per cent on ifs Capital. BOWEN FREEZING WORKS. These Works at date of fids report are still o|>erating and will probably continue for another month When it is estimated about 3(1.500 . head of cattle will have been treated compared with 31,100 head for the 1938 season. . MAIN. ROADS. Construction lias been continued on the road between Bowen and Home Hill and good fra tile conditions are now in evidence over most of the route. It is estimated that this road will lie completed in about 18 months. Nothing so far has been done on flic road between- Bowen and Proserpine which Is in a deplorable condition. It is understood that the Main Roads Commission has this section listed for attention in the near future. Road conditions between Bowen and the Bowen Coalfield remain laid. It is likely that: (Tie road recently constructed to the Upper Don will he utilised as a section of n now route via Mossvale to Collinsville which will greatly Improve travelling conditions. Tills road no doubt will even tually serve as'a feeder to the Inland road from Brisbane to Charters Towers now listed for construction for defence purposes, AERODROME. The gravelling of runways on the aerodrome permits of landings in alt weathers. Following the substitution of "Douglas” for - “Stinson”' aircraft on the northern service Bowen was deprived of its daily service but a change back to “Stinson” machines has restored this service, and we are again enjoying a mail and passenger service north and south daily. PUBLIC BATHS. The original estimate of £BOOO for our baths was found to be inadequate and a further loan of £2OOO was obtained. This too proved insufficient and construction has been at: a standstill for some time pend ing the result of representation for another loan of £1250. It has been announced this further amount lias been granted and so it is probable construction will be resumed at a early date. GENERAL. . Attention was devoted to matters relating to postal, railway, school and other services during the year. ' Consideration was given to the possibility of a factory being established here for the processing of fruit and vegetables. The jiroduction of oil from coal to till a national need in time, of war was again advocated Representations outlining the facilities offering at Bowen in respect of the establishment, of works in North Queensland for manufacture of superphosphate fertiliser were made to Mount Isa Mines Limited which company was considering the question of undertaking such a project. In submitting resolutions for debate at the annual Conference of Queensland Chambers, the Chamber advocated taxation on u wealth scale for the upkeep of hospitals in preference to the present inequitable (method of land taxation. A resolution dealing with the tendency to segregation of our alien population. Advocacy of the more general use of pulverised coal In lieu of oil. Excessive charges in respect of postal and telephone services and recommendations for expediting the construction of the Pacific highway. Unfortunately, on account of the outbreak of war, it was deemed advisable to abandon the conference on this occasion. In concluding tills report, I desire to (hank our State member, Mr. E, J. Rlordan and our Federal member, Mr. G. Martens, for attention to matters submitted to them from time to time. Thanks are also due to the press for the publicity given to the business of the Chamber and to

the officials of various government departments for Information in the compilation of our yearly statistics. I am also grateful to those members of the Chamber who have regularly attended our meetings and assisted in the debates. Thanks are also due to our honorary auditors, Messrs. A. B; Moore and E. It. Atkinson. ' Appended are the usual statistical figures relating to our district.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

August 5th, 1939. FROM A HORNET. To the Editor.

Thanking you, Mr Editor, Yours faithfully, “FEEL THE STING.”

J. L. JONES, Sec. Miners Union, Scottville.

Hear Sir,—I notice in your issue of July 24 Inst in the Shire Council notes that a tractor, meaning singular, has damaged the road between Don Kail-

why Bridge and Delta Siding. Coun cillors Bishop and 6. Pott seem to be the complainants. They should both know that more than one tractor has been driven oyer the same road. I notice the Foreman found the damage missing. What I would like to know is did Councillor Bishop report Coun cillor G. Pott, or did Cr. G,. Pott emu late George Washington. I am refer ring to the two tractors that plowed the ground G. Pott is farming at. Don Delta. I saw those two tractors .on tile Delta Koad. .How far they went after crossing the river I leave G. Pott to tell. The Whngnratta Shire Laun dry may ns well have my dirty linen, I would like- Or. Bishop to report to Hie next Council meeting how many stock he hag straying on the Shire roads. How many pigs he has on his farm. How .far away, from his house the pig stye is situated. Is the natur al drainage from the pig stye into the River? Does his sulky travel on the Shire roads without proper lights? You. are not immune, Giddy.

! ScottvlUe, 2/8/38. To the Editor, Bowen Independent, Dear Sir,—. With further reference to the dispute at Consolidated Colliery, Scottville, I wish to state that on the Ist August, a Union Official from the South arrived on the field, to gain first hand information- ana if possible effect a settlement. At a meeting it was decided that the local committee accompany the Union official for Inter view with manager. This official point ed out to him that the men were, and always have been willing to resume work on pre-stoppage conditions, and that he, the manager, was committing a breach of Clause 57 of the Award by not opening the Mine; The official then rea<x of the Award which is as follows: "When a dispute occurs at any colliery which cannot be settled by the Manager, Overman, and Scrutin eers, work shall proceed under the con ditions prevailing before the dispute occurred, and the dispute shall immed iately be referred to the Conciliation Board. The Manager then said that Mr. Conway, Manager of . the State Mine, told him he takes men from the list for employment only if they suit him. The local committee, emphatic ally denied this statement and chal lenged the manager to prove It. The Manager then asked the committee, if the matter went to Court would they abide by its decision. The Committee considered this question, not only cheeky and insolent but rather comical seeing that he is reserving the right to break the Court’s ruling by not .obey ing Clause 57. However the committee pointed out that if the Court gave a decision, it also had the necessary pow er to enforce its decision being carried out. Also they showed him a cutting taken from the “Queensland Times,” an Ipswich paper, which circulates - in the largest coal mining district in Queensland. It reads: "Mr. Thomas, Secretary of Colliery Proprietors’ As sociation, notified the Union, that he had given instructions to the Consol idated Company, to resume work, on pre-stoppage conditions, and dispute would be referred to the Court.” The Manager.then seemed to get quite up set, waving his hands about he said, “Run away I won’t listen to any more, the mine will only open on ray condi tions, I am not worrying, our custom ers are getting all the coal they re quire elsewhere." It will be seen that quire elsewhere.'’ It will be , seen therefore that the management has adopted an arrogant, aggravating atti tude towards us. We are determined to resist such methods ns these and have the backing of the organised workers both morally and financially throughout North Queensland.

OUR MEMBER.

ROBES OF OFFICE NOT NEEDED IN A DEMOCRACY.

Speaking in the Legislative Assem bly on August 31, our Member (Mr. E. J. Riordan) gave the following address:

ail-. RIORDAN: I wish to offer my congratulations to you, Mr. Speaker,' on your elevation, to the Speakership, l am pleased that up to the present, at least, you have discarded the robes of ofllce. I have no doubt that you will carry out the duties attaching to your position with just ns much dignity without those loose, flowing robes. As the lion, member for South Brisbane said, when conducting you into the chair, it is not the clothes that make the man. The wearing of robes of ofllce may be all right in other parts of the world, where pomp and dignity must be displayed, but they are alto gether unnecessary in a democratic country like Australia. If the explan ation of their absence is not that your tailor is slow on the job, I hope that you will continue in your present re solve, and not wear the robes that have been Worn by previous occupants of the chair. " I also desire to congratulate the mover and seconder of the Address in Reply on their speeches. The hon. member for Charters Towers had pre vious experience in this House, but the hon member for Townsville was making his debut. Both hon. members made very excellent contributions to this debate. It is only we members who have been in this House for but a short period who can appreciate the ordeal of making a maiden speech. TRIBUTE TO “MOSSY” HYNES. Since the first session of this Par liament we have lost three very fine members In the late Mr. “Mossy” Hynes, the hon. member for Towns ville; the late Mr. W. J. .Wellington, the hon. member for. Charters Towers; and the late Mr. G. Pollock, the hon. member for Gregory. As to Mr. Hynes, I am sure that both sides regret his passing. He was kindly to a fault. He could always see the other fellow’s point of view. I know of no man who as more capable, or who exercised more, kindly instincts in discharging •the onerous duties of his ofllce. We ou this side regret the passing of a great mate. When the history of the Labour Party in this State comes to be written we know that his name will figure prominently in it. The late Mr. Wellington was n man who hud battled hard and successfully for the people whom he represented for such a long period in this Cham ber. Before he entered Parliament he was an organiser for various local branch unions. He could always be relied on to put forward the best argu ments in the interests of those whom he represented. He was never found wanting in . his duty. He was a man who had been victimised for his. opin ions in days when it was a crime to be a Labour man. The late Mr. Pollock carried out his duties in. this House with great dis tinction to himself and Parliament. I regret very much that certain people have seen fit when travelling through this State to speak disparagingly of him and to drag his name in the dirt. Of course, suck conduct is In Weep ing with the policy of persons who are prone to besmirch the names of those who cannot defend themselves. ..If the late Mr. Pollock had been living those people would have spoken favourably of him, but with their tongues in their cheeks. I hesitate to allude to such a matter, but it is very uncharitable to see a person attacked when it is not possible for him to defend himself. NEGLECTED BOWEN. During the recess the hon. member for East Toowoomba, who appears to he the travelling official or unofficial organiser of the Country Party, visit ed various electorates in North Queensland, including the Bowen elec torate. The Bowen "Independent" re ports the lion, member ns saying much about tile neglect of Bowen by past Governments. He has also repeated that statement in this House. He-fur thor stated that Townsville should never have been chosen as a settle ment. That remark has also been sup ported by a Mr. Collinson In an ad dress before the Historical Society. The hon. member for East Toowoomba also said that the Great Northern Railway should never have started at Townsville. When he speaks on these matters he must not forget that Townsville was established and the G.N.R. constructed from that town by a political party of the same colour as himself. According to a report that appeared in the Bowen paper, the hon. member for East Toowoomba said that he was leaving by his private rail conch at 2 o'clock in the morning. I am pleased to know that, country members arc able to travel to their electorates in comfort. The next time I have to visit my electorate I shall' apply to‘the'Min ister-for a rail conch, too. T know the privilege'has not been extended to the leader of the Opposition. It was only at election time that the hon. member for West Moreton was granted that privilege. I do not know of any. other occasion on which lie obtained that privilege, but it there were other oc casions, the fact wlll 'lehd support to

the argument : that nil country mem bers should receive the privilege, too. If "the Lender of the Opposition has not enjoyed tliiivprlvllege, he should make application for it unless he ex pects' the hoh;! member to usurp his position 1 as leader of the Country Party and :! Leader of Opposition. "FOSSILISED CITIZENS.” The hon, member for East Too woomba may well .be surprised that the Bowen rawlay station had been shifted two miles out of the town. I mention for the , information of the hon. member that the people who en tertained him while he was in Bowen —some old and respected citizens, fos silised members of the Chamber of Commerce—rare the people who are re sponsible for the shifting of that sta tion. I have that on the word of the former Commissioner for Railways, the late J. W. Davidson. He told me that a deputation of citizens waited upon him and said they thought it necessary , to remove the station to n place that would be the most central part of the town when it developed as they thought It would. That was In the days when ;wc had dreams of a North Queensland iron and steel works in; BowenV 1 That project could have been carried into effect If the money had been made available when It was applled for by the then- Premier, 1 Mr. B. G. Theodore, and It would now have been a great 1 national asset — es pecially when we cannot fill orders for .iron and steel from overseas. TIDE’ BOWEN STEEL WORKS. Of course, . It may be argued that this is a time of crises, when there is an abnormal demand for these pro ducts, but it. would have been a great asset at any time. Mr. Theodore show ed great vision and foresight when he made the suggestion that the Govern ment borrow £5,000,000 or £6,000,000 for the establishment of an iron and steel works at Bowen. Vested interests made It impossible for Mr., Theodore to borrow that money. It may be said that is past history, but it is well worth repeating that if we had an iron and steel works in Bowen today we should have a population in and around Bowen of 30,000 or 40,000 people. In support of that statement I mention the fact that the iron and steel works at Newcastle gives employ ment, directly and Indirectly to approx imately, 25,000 people. Even if there had been a loss during the stages of development—a loss that has occurred- In other industries till they reached a productive stage—it would now have been a very profitable industry. Profits do not; count for everything with me. After all is said and done, it Is the duty of every hon. member to do the best he can,.first for Australia and next for QdfSiislahd. There is a great awakening Iti this State and in Australia to our resposibllities and the need for developing this country. If we-are going to be hamstrung by little Australians who have no regard for the development of this State, the quicker we get it over and the quicker democracy disappears the better. A democracy can be maintained only by giving to each and 'every person with in it the right to work and live decent ly. If we full to do-4hls, we can ex pect other forms of government to be substituted. No doubt, hon. members opposite regard my remarka as the ut terances of a Communist, but that is not so. They are made by nn Austra lian with an Australian outlook. DEVELOPMENT of state mine NEEDED;' On the proposal - to ,establish iron works at Bowen the Bowen Harbour Board was committed to the expendi ture of approximately £200,000 for the construction Of a new, wharf and coal transporter. On the : abandonment of that proposal.lt was-left with these on its hands and it was then suggested that, ns there were large coal deposits at Collinsville, 60 miles away, endeav ours should be made :to Increase the export trade in coal. Yet, deapite / tlie unlimited supply of coal in the neigh bourhood,. Bowen is actually today in the position of being unable to fill local orders. Owlng to lack of devel opment in the mines. If a strike or stoppage takes place ;-in any one, or j dors for coal go to Newcastle, outside the State. ;.The sooner ;we'get down to bedrock and 'the .sooner’ the-Govern ment set aside money'for the develop ment. of the mine, so that a greater number of miners can . be 'employed, and thus make it possible' to meet j emergency orders, the; better for Queensland. The Stage has been reached In the Bowen pren'.at which no greater quantity of. coal cau bo produced, owing to lack of develop ment. MEAT QUOTA SHOULD BE INCREASED. The commission on transport recom mended that £llO,OOO be written off the debt of the Bowen Harbour Board. That would relieve ..the, ; Board, but, unfortunately, It is. making applica tion for a loan for-(dredging and ex tending wharves to accommodate the modern motor, vessels'that come to Queensland to - lift chilled and frozen beef for overseas. The present wharves are Inadequate. I have pre viously pointed out that there- is n saving of 18 to 20 days In the trans port of chilled beef overseas if boats go through the Torres Strait. The

Unit consideration of tills State Parlia ment should be the development of Queensland, and one factor would be an increase in the overseas trade in chilled beef. As "part of the British Kmpirc we should be able to retain, if not increase, our present quota, night ly. there should be an increase and not a decrease in the quota. Mr. Muller: We are nut lining our quota. Mr. XtIOIIDAN: As the hon. inember has pointed out, we are not tilling our own quota, but-an extension would mean greater wealth to the State of Queensland, and consequently nddl-' tlonal employment and a higher stan dard of living for our people. These are matters that concern us as Queens landers and Australians. GRIM RECOLLECTIONS OF RELIEF. Without appearing to be sarcastic and with no desire to ridicule anoth er’s point of view, X take exception to some of the comments on unemploy ment made by Opposition members in this debate.. What is the,good of go ing back Into the past? We must look to the future and see whether we can do greater things for the people who are in the unenviable position of being unemployed in this State. Each and every hon. member opposite who has spoken has said: "What are you doing about the unemployed? You stole £220,000 from the people of the State. You have made it possible in that way to have a surplus of £14,000.” What does all that matter? That has all gone. Let us look to the future and see if we can build up something that is better for the people who are In the unenviable position of being without work. I do not want to go back into the past, because I have some very grim recollections' of it. 1 liave been unem ployed'and on relief work. I can re member the Introduction of the relief scheme by the Moore Government. I suppose at that time they thought that it was a measure that would bet ter the' conditions of the people, who were receiving nothing then. They proposed that a man who had a wife and two children should go to work for two days a week and receive £1 for the work he did. The criticism of hon. members opposite today and for the past week has been of.the condi ■ tioiiy that now exist. They ask us what we are'doing. Mr. Dart: They are much worse to day. Mr. Rlordanr pf course the farmer from Wynnum with his seaside re sort and everything else would know what the conditions on relief work are. The conditions of the relief work er today are not all that I or any oth er hon. member on this side of the House, including the Cabinet, would like them to be, but he is better off even on rations today tha n he was when ho had to work for his , susten ance, monetary or otherwise, in the days gone by. - Mr. Maher; No, nonsense. MR. XIIORDAN: I challenge the Opposition-to prove that ho is not. In 11129, when they introduced their scheme —- Mr. Daniel: He got £3 a week. Mr. RIOUDAN: He got £1 a week if he had a wife and two children. He was paid that for two days’ work. As a matter of fact, if a man had his own home, he-was questioned, and • challenged'ln those-days, and if there

was any other bread-winner of any kind in the house his allowance of work was reduced considerably.' Hon. Members opposite''cair abhleve nothing by denying that, because I know what I.am talking about. I say that tho man who is receiving rations today la better off than whe u he was working under the system introduced by the Moo.re Government. Mr. Dart; And you are satisfied. (Concluded in next IJjgu?)) •

THE PRESS BALL

EXCEEDS PREVIOUS SUCCESS.

The 1939 Press Ball took place on Friday night and once again hit a high note of enjoyment for the large at tendance. Unlike most ball functions,

there was a full attendance early in the night, so that before 9 p.m. the fun was under way. It continued un ceasingly until the small hours, with two orchestras keeping the dancing continuous and lively. The decorating of the hall was car ried out in the black and white colours of the press, and the red and gold of the Ambulance, a very good effect be ing achieved with a myriad streamers descending from the ceiling, and in a fancy pattern on the walls. Vari coloured balloons added to the gaiety of the scene. An unusual feature, was the great sign suspended over the stage, which proclaimed in large glit tering silver letters Unit this was the ‘Press Ball 1939.” The lavish distribution of novelties at frequent intervals, dancing competi tions, and the-new-crazy dances kept everyone in very good mood through out, and several twilight waltzs were very popular. Interest was keen in the Old Time Waltz competition, as the contestants in that graceful dance were thinned down to the winners, Mr. George Weekes and Miss Pat Conser dyne, who well deserved the prize. The judges found the decision hard to arrive at in the Foxtrot Competi tion, and finally awarded a tie to Mr. and Mrs. T. Donohue and Mr. Forder add . Miss .less Cordes, both couples dancing extremely well before, an ad miring crowd. The Crazy Dances: which have swept the world have found many devotees in Bowen, and this was the first ball at which they were all featured. The star item was the Most Humorous Lambeth Walk, and everybody joined in what was the most laughable Lam beth Walk ever staged locally. Knees were slapped harder, and the “Oi’s” rose louder than ever. The prize went to the pianortiming and wise cracking Mr. Bill Cullum and his part ner Miss Kath. Burns. Their’s was an epic effort. The strains of “Neath the Spreading Chestnut Tree” brought the crowd to their feet for this new dance, and they loved it. This action song about the goings-on under a certain chestnut tree gained a permanent place in our dance programmes. Another new but not quite, so crazy dance in the Palais Glide was next introduced, and proved just as popular. Interest was very keen in the Swell of the Ball Competition, and canvass ing for votes for Lost principal candidates went on until the voting closed. The wlpne£prOyed to-be .Kick (“Siiiicho”) Woods, 5 the jfiivojirite, who netted 88 votes, with the runner-up a Merinda candidatei’in Mcrvyn Perkins, who,gained 78 votes;'Third place went to Glen (“Buster") Horan with 51. Mr. Woods, his face matching his hair in colour, was taken protesting!}' to tiie stage to be decorated with a pale blue sash, 'suitably inscribed, and a silver loving cup. He was quite over come by ins unsuspected popularity. Supper was served in buffet fashion ip a marquee, and proved very pjalat able. The supper', room was tastefully decorated in the Ambulance colours, a tribute to tiie lady workers responsible for the dainties, and to the efficient humanitarian organisation in whoso aid the Ball, was devoted. With the coming of midnight there was a continuous demand “Where is Ihe “Nightie” - ' and’when that scandal sheet did arrive there.was a stampede to obtain copies. Everyone. had con tributed to its spicy 'columns, each person at the ball having been given a card on which a Vieht par was to he written about best friends—the kind of thing your best, friend usually does not tell you. These had been, duly set up and included in tiie “Nightie’ by the “Independent”- staff, and, amuse ment was Intense as the dancing cens ed for a while until ' everyone had skimmed through its columns. Then it was stowed away in pockets and handbags to be digested at leisure, and the fun was on again. At one a.m. the popular hot dog supper took place, and these tasty morsels were greatly-'ih demand.''Great was the general satisfaction and sense of good * time as the' ball draw to a close. Great also'was the satisfac tion of the organism's at the success ef their function, and of the Ambul ance stalwarts, who netted" a profit for their funds of over- £43. During the course of the evening, Mr. H. Currie (Chairman, Q.A.T.8.) made a sincere speech of thanks to the staff of the “Independent" and Ambulance sup porters who had worked so hard for such good results.

Obituary.

ALICE ELLISON.

The passion of Alice Ellison, relict of the late John Ellison, on Thursday last removed a resident of forty years’ standing from our midst. Born at

Brighton (England) seventy-two years ago she- came to Australia as. a young woman and travelled extensively in this country with her husband and before settling in Bowen at the end of last century. Her husband predeceas ed her by a number of years and she had since resided with her only son, Mr. James Ellison. in George Street. Though small in stature, the late Mrs. Hllison possessed plenty of spirit and a hardy independence.. She fought bravely against the advancing years, and even on the day prior to her pass ing still insisted on helping herself, though almost totally bedridden. While insisting on fending tor herself she had a kindly and generous' sym pathy for those less able to do so, and was quick to assist anybody'. Men on the track during the depression-years, camping in Denison Park, close to her home, often had occasion, to bless her kindness, but found she had a sharp tongue to repress, any offer of thanks. She believed firmly in asking no fav ours for herself, though quick to give. Those who knew ’her were quick to appreciate her many good qualities, and will Join us in. expressing deep sympathy for her son and his family, Tlie funeral left the residence at 5.3o p.m. on Thursday afternoon, Rev. Stephens performing the last, sad rites at the graveside.
